Article.Abstract: Murine experimental allergic encephalomyelitis (EAE) is a useful model for the demyelinating, autoimmune disease multiple sclerosis. In the EAE system, the immunodominant N-terminal epitope of myelin basic protein (MBP) is an unusually short, weakly binding peptide antigen which elicits highly biased TCR chain usage. In the 2.2 A crystal structure of I-A(u)/MBP1-11 complex, only MBP residues 1-7 are bound toward one end of the peptide binding cleft. The fourth residue of MBP1-11 is located in an incompatible p6 pocket of I-A(u), thus explaining the short half-life of I-A(u) complexed with Ac1-11. MBP peptides extended at the C terminus of Ac1-11 result in dramatic affinity increases, likely attributed to register shifting to a higher affinity cryptic epitope, which could potentially mask the presentation of the immunodominant MBP1-11 peptide during thymic education.
Article.ArticleTitle: Structural snapshot of aberrant antigen presentation linked to autoimmunity: the immunodominant epitope of MBP complexed with I-Au.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Microbiology and Immunology, Stanford University School of Medicine, CA 94305, USA.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Epitopes, T-Lymphocyte;Histocompatibility Antigens Class II;Immunodominant Epitopes;Macromolecular Substances;Myelin Basic Protein;Peptide Fragments;myelin basic protein 1-11;Arginine

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: The epitope is an analog of peptide MBP(1-11). To cater for the requirement of an in vivo posttranslational acetylation of the MBP N-terminus, a Glycine residue was added at the beginning of the peptide, at position MBP-0. This residue mimics the acetyl needed group. Also, to enhance the binding affinity of the epitope to the MHC, a mutation was introduced: K4 -> Y4. Next, three additional residues from the leader sequence S-3, R-2, G-1 remained at the N-terminus as part of the epitope. Finally, at the peptide C-terminus, the first eight residues from the peptide linker remain as part of the peptide sequence.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The C-terminus of the epitope was covalently linked the the N-terminus of the MHC β-chain through an eight residue synthetic peptide linker. The residues of the linker peptide are listed as part of the epitope chain. Electron density was disordered for epitope residues P: Q8 - G11; and for the eight residues of the peptide linker. Only the main chain of the residue P:Q8 is visible in the electron density.

ThreeDimensionalStructureOfComplex.Comments: [|P-3: S-3; P-2: R-2; P-1: G-1; P2: G0; P3: A1; P4: S2; P5: Q3; P6: Y4; P7: R5; P8: P6; P9: S7; P10: Q8; |] The distinguishing feature of this structure is that only the first seven epitope residues are located in the middle and C-terminal part of the epitope binding groove. Epitope residues 8-11 extend beyond the binding groove. As a result the peptide register is shifted to the right by two positions, such that residue P: A1 occupies pocket P3. This also means that in vivo, the P1, P2 pockets are empty. The available information on MHC-Epitope interactions is given below: The main chains of residues P: G-1, G0; form hydrogen bonds to MHC residues in a way similar to that seen for normal length peptides. The empty P1 pocket is occupied by several water molecules. Pocket P4 is only partially occupied by S2 and the remaining space is filled by a water molecule. The side chain of residue P: Y4 is deeply buried in pocket P6. This pocket also contains water molecules. MHC residues involved in the formation of this pocket are A: N62, T65; B: F11, Y30. TCR binding: Because of the unique binding mode of the epitope to the MHC, residues P: Q3, P6; which would normally point downward in MHC pockets, are now solvent exposed and comprise TCR-contact residues. Residue P: R5; is the third TCR-contact residue. MHC residues A: F24, F54; B: V28 form a region that contacts the TCR. Conformational comparison of the MHC in the complex with structures of other H-2-IA alleles: The conformation of the MHC backbone is very similar to that of other H-2-IA molecules. The only difference is a displacement of a turn in the MHC α helix, in the region of residues B: 60-71. This results in a narrower end of the peptide binding groove. Also, pocket P4 is substantially smaller because of the substitution : L26 -> Y26.
